instruments.title: WHO-5 Well-Being Index
instruments.description: A short questionnaire consisting of 5 simple and non-invasive questions, which tap into the subjective well-being of the respondent. The WHO-5 is among the most widely used questionnaires assessing subjective psychological well-being.
instruments.source: World Health Organization (WHO), 1998. Bech P, Olsen LR, Kjoller M, Rasmussen NK. Measuring well-being rather than the absence of distress symptoms: a comparison of the SF-36 Mental Health subscale and the WHO-Five well-being scale. Int J Methods Psychiatr Res. 2003;12(2):85-91.
instruments.population: General population aged 9 years and older

questions.text: I have felt cheerful and in good spirits

options.label: Less than half of the time
More than half of the time

questions.text: I have felt calm and relaxed

options.label: Less than half of the time
More than half of the time

questions.text: I have felt active and vigorous

options.label: Less than half of the time
More than half of the time

questions.text: I woke up feeling fresh and rested

options.label: Less than half of the time
More than half of the time

questions.text: My daily life has been filled with things that interest me

options.label: Less than half of the time
More than half of the time

clinical_concern.message: Score indicates poor well-being; consider depression screening

psychometric_properties.validity: Strong concurrent validity with other well-being measures

instruments.title: Perceived Stress Scale-10 (PSS-10)
instruments.description: The Perceived Stress Scale (PSS) is a widely used psychological instrument for measuring the perception of stress. It assesses how unpredictable, uncontrollable, and overloaded respondents find their lives.
instruments.source: Cohen, S., Kamarck, T., & Mermelstein, R. (1983). A global measure of perceived stress. Journal of Health and Social Behavior, 24(4), 385–396. Public Domain.
instruments.population: Adults and adolescents aged 12 and older

questions.text: In the last month, how often have you been upset because of something that happened unexpectedly?
In the last month, how often have you felt that you were unable to control the important things in your life?
In the last month, how often have you felt nervous and stressed?
In the last month, how often have you felt confident about your ability to handle your personal problems?
In the last month, how often have you felt that things were going your way?
In the last month, how often have you found that you could not cope with all the things that you had to do?
In the last month, how often have you been able to control irritations in your life?
In the last month, how often have you felt that you were on top of things?
In the last month, how often have you been angered because of things that were outside of your control?
In the last month, how often have you felt difficulties were piling up so high that you could not overcome them?

total_score.description: Sum of all items after reverse scoring of items 4, 5, 7, and 8 (range: 0–40)

stress_level.description: Categorical assessment based on total perceived stress

clinical_concern.message: High stress levels may warrant clinical evaluation or support

instruments.title: Depression, Anxiety and Stress Scale-21 (DASS-21)
instruments.description: The DASS-21 is a 21-item self-report scale designed to measure the negative emotional states of depression, anxiety and stress. It is widely used in both clinical and research settings.
instruments.source: Lovibond, S.H. & Lovibond, P.F. (1995). Manual for the Depression Anxiety Stress Scales (2nd Ed.). Sydney: Psychology Foundation.
instruments.license: Free for research and clinical use

questions.text: I found it hard to wind down

options.label: Did not apply to me at all
Applied to me to some degree, or some of the time
Applied to me to a considerable degree, or a good part of time
Applied to me very much, or most of the time

questions.text: I was aware of dryness of my mouth

options.label: Did not apply to me at all
Applied to me to some degree, or some of the time
Applied to me to a considerable degree, or a good part of time
Applied to me very much, or most of the time

questions.text: I couldn't seem to experience any positive feeling at all

options.label: Did not apply to me at all
Applied to me to some degree, or some of the time
Applied to me to a considerable degree, or a good part of time
Applied to me very much, or most of the time

options.label: Did not apply to me at all
Applied to me to some degree, or some of the time

Applied to me very much, or most of the time

options.label: Did not apply to me at all

options.label: Did not apply to me at all

Applied to me very much, or most of the time

options.label: Did not apply to me at all

options.label: Did not apply to me at all

Applied to me very much, or most of the time

options.label: Did not apply to me at all

Applied to me very much, or most of the time

options.label: Did not apply to me at all

options.label: Did not apply to me at all
Applied to me to some degree, or some of the time

options.label: Did not apply to me at all

options.label: Did not apply to me at all
Applied to me to some degree, or some of the time

Applied to me very much, or most of the time

options.label: Did not apply to me at all
Applied to me to some degree, or some of the time

Applied to me very much, or most of the time

options.label: Did not apply to me at all
Applied to me to some degree, or some of the time
Applied to me to a considerable degree, or a good part of time
Applied to me very much, or most of the time

options.label: Did not apply to me at all
Applied to me to some degree, or some of the time
Applied to me to a considerable degree, or a good part of time
Applied to me very much, or most of the time

options.label: Did not apply to me at all

options.label: Did not apply to me at all
Applied to me to some degree, or some of the time
Applied to me to a considerable degree, or a good part of time
Applied to me very much, or most of the time

depression_final.description: Depression score normalized to DASS-42 scale

anxiety_final.description: Anxiety score normalized to DASS-42 scale

stress_final.description: Stress score normalized to DASS-42 scale

depression_clinical_flag.message: Moderate or higher depression symptoms detected

anxiety_clinical_flag.message: Moderate or higher anxiety symptoms detected

stress_clinical_flag.message: Moderate or higher stress levels detected

instruments.title: Warwick-Edinburgh Mental Well-being Scale (WEMWBS)
instruments.description: The Warwick-Edinburgh Mental Well-being Scale (WEMWBS) is a 14-item scale of positively worded statements, developed to monitor mental wellbeing in the general population and evaluate interventions designed to improve it.
instruments.source: Tennant, R., Hiller, L., Fishwick, R., Platt, S., Joseph, S., Weich, S., Parkinson, J., Secker, J., & Stewart-Brown, S. (2007). The Warwick-Edinburgh Mental Well-being Scale (WEMWBS): development and UK validation. Health and Quality of Life Outcomes, 5, 63.

questions.text: I've been feeling optimistic about the future
I've been feeling useful
I've been feeling relaxed
I've been feeling interested in other people
I've had energy to spare
I've been dealing with problems well
I've been thinking clearly
I've been feeling good about myself
I've been feeling close to other people
I've been feeling confident
I've been able to make up my own mind about things
I've been feeling loved
I've been interested in new things
I've been feeling cheerful

total_score.description: Total WEMWBS score (range: 14–70). Higher scores reflect greater mental wellbeing.

wellbeing_level.description: Interpretive categories for wellbeing scores. Used for population comparisons and screening.

clinical_concern.message: Low mental wellbeing may indicate a need for additional support or follow-up

instruments.title: Maslach Burnout Inventory - Human Services Survey (MBI-HSS)
instruments.description: The MBI-HSS is designed to assess burnout in human services and healthcare professionals. This research-adapted version is based on the original MBI framework but uses different items for non-commercial, academic use.
instruments.source: Adapted from: Maslach, C., Jackson, S. E., & Leiter, M. P. (1996). Maslach Burnout Inventory Manual (3rd ed.). Consulting Psychologists Press.
instruments.license: Research adaptation – Original MBI is copyrighted

questions.text: I feel emotionally drained from my work

options.label: A few times a year or less

questions.text: I feel used up at the end of the workday

options.label: A few times a year or less

questions.text: I feel fatigued when I get up and have to face another day on the job

options.label: A few times a year or less

questions.text: Working with people all day is really a strain for me

options.label: A few times a year or less

questions.text: I feel burned out from my work

options.label: A few times a year or less

questions.text: I feel frustrated by my job

options.label: A few times a year or less

questions.text: I feel I'm working too hard on my job

options.label: A few times a year or less

questions.text: Working directly with people puts too much stress on me

options.label: A few times a year or less

questions.text: I feel like I'm at the end of my rope

options.label: A few times a year or less

questions.text: I treat some recipients as if they were impersonal objects

options.label: A few times a year or less

questions.text: I have become more callous toward people since I took this job

options.label: A few times a year or less

questions.text: I worry that this job is hardening me emotionally

options.label: A few times a year or less

questions.text: I don't really care what happens to some recipients

options.label: A few times a year or less

questions.text: I feel recipients blame me for some of their problems

options.label: A few times a year or less

questions.text: I deal very effectively with the problems of my recipients

options.label: A few times a year or less

questions.text: I feel I'm positively influencing other people's lives through my work

options.label: A few times a year or less

questions.text: I feel very energetic

options.label: A few times a year or less

questions.text: I can easily understand how my recipients feel about things

options.label: A few times a year or less

questions.text: I can easily create a relaxed atmosphere with my recipients

options.label: A few times a year or less

questions.text: I feel exhilarated after working closely with my recipients

options.label: A few times a year or less

questions.text: I have accomplished many worthwhile things in this job

options.label: A few times a year or less

questions.text: In my work, I deal with emotional problems very calmly

options.label: A few times a year or less

emotional_exhaustion.description: Emotional exhaustion subscale (range: 0-54, higher = greater burnout)

personal_accomplishment.description: Personal accomplishment subscale (range: 0-48, higher = lower burnout)

burnout_risk.message: High risk for burnout — consider interventions or professional support

severe_burnout_risk.message: Severe burnout risk — immediate intervention recommended

psychometric_properties.validity: Extensively validated across human services populations; good construct and discriminant validity

instruments.title: Rosenberg Self-Esteem Scale (RSES)
instruments.description: The Rosenberg Self-Esteem Scale is a 10-item Likert scale designed to assess global self-worth by evaluating both positive and negative feelings about the self.
instruments.source: Rosenberg, M. (1965). Society and the Adolescent Self-Image. Princeton, NJ: Princeton University Press. Public Domain.

questions.text: On the whole, I am satisfied with myself
At times I think I am no good at all
I feel that I have a number of good qualities
I am able to do things as well as most other people
I feel I do not have much to be proud of
I certainly feel useless at times
I feel that I'm a person of worth, at least on an equal plane with others
I wish I could have more respect for myself
All in all, I am inclined to feel that I am a failure
I take a positive attitude toward myself

total_score.description: Total self-esteem score (range: 0–30). Reverse scoring is applied to negatively worded items (q2, q5, q6, q8, q9).

low_self_esteem_flag.message: Low self-esteem detected — may benefit from additional evaluation or support

adults.reference: Schmitt, D. P., & Allik, J. (2005). Simultaneous administration of the Rosenberg Self-Esteem Scale in 53 nations. Journal of Personality and Social Psychology, 89(4), 623–642.

instruments.title: International Personality Item Pool Big Five (IPIP-50)
instruments.description: A 50-item measure of the Big Five personality dimensions: Extraversion, Agreeableness, Conscientiousness, Neuroticism, and Openness to Experience. All items are in the public domain.
instruments.source: Goldberg, L. R. (1992). The development of markers for the Big-Five factor structure. Psychological Assessment, 4, 26-42. Public Domain via IPIP.ori.org

questions.text: Am the life of the party
Feel little concern for others
Am always prepared
Get stressed out easily
Have a rich vocabulary
Don't talk a lot
Am interested in people
Leave my belongings around
Am relaxed most of the time
Have difficulty understanding abstract ideas
Feel comfortable around people
Insult people
Pay attention to details
Worry about things
Have a vivid imagination
Keep in the background
Sympathize with others' feelings
Make a mess of things
Seldom feel blue
Am not interested in abstract ideas
Start conversations
Am not interested in other people's problems
Get chores done right away
Am easily disturbed
Have excellent ideas
Have little to say
Have a soft heart
Often forget to put things back in their proper place
Get upset easily
Do not have a good imagination
Talk to a lot of different people at parties
Am not really interested in others
Like order
Change my mood a lot
Am quick to understand things
Don't like to draw attention to myself
Take time out for others
Shirk my duties
Have frequent mood swings
Use difficult words
Don't mind being the center of attention
Am not really interested in abstract ideas
Follow a schedule
Get irritated easily
Spend time reflecting on things
Am quiet around strangers
Make people feel at ease
Am exacting in my work
Often feel blue
Am full of ideas

psychometric_properties.validity: Strong factorial validity and convergent validity with NEO-PI-R

instruments.title: Ten Item Personality Inventory (TIPI)
instruments.description: A very brief 10-item measure of the Big Five personality dimensions. Designed for research situations where time is limited.
instruments.source: Gosling, S. D., Rentfrow, P. J., & Swann, W. B. (2003). A very brief measure of the Big-Five personality domains. Journal of Research in Personality, 37, 504-528. Free for research use.

questions.text: Extraverted, enthusiastic
Critical, quarrelsome
Dependable, self-disciplined
Anxious, easily upset
Open to new experiences, complex
Reserved, quiet
Sympathetic, warm
Disorganized, careless
Calm, emotionally stable
Conventional, uncreative

psychometric_properties.validity: Adequate convergent validity given brevity; correlates .65-.87 with Big Five Inventory

instruments.title: Satisfaction with Life Scale (SWLS)
instruments.description: A 5-item scale designed to measure global cognitive judgments of one's life satisfaction. One of the most widely used measures of life satisfaction.
instruments.source: Diener, E., Emmons, R. A., Larsen, R. J., & Griffin, S. (1985). The Satisfaction with Life Scale. Journal of Personality Assessment, 49, 71-75. Free for research use.

questions.text: In most ways my life is close to my ideal
The conditions of my life are excellent
I am satisfied with my life
So far I have gotten the important things I want in life
If I could live my life over, I would change almost nothing

psychometric_properties.validity: Strong convergent validity with other well-being measures and life satisfaction ratings

instruments.title: Positive and Negative Affect Schedule (PANAS)
instruments.description: A 20-item scale measuring positive and negative affect. Can be used to assess mood states over different time periods (moment, day, week, year, general).
instruments.source: Watson, D., Clark, L. A., & Tellegen, A. (1988). Development and validation of brief measures of positive and negative affect: the PANAS scales. Journal of Personality and Social Psychology, 54, 1063-1070. Free for research use.

questions.text: Interested

options.label: Very slightly or not at all

questions.instruction: This scale consists of a number of words that describe different feelings and emotions. Indicate to what extent you feel this way right now:

questions.text: Distressed

options.label: Very slightly or not at all

questions.text: Excited

options.label: Very slightly or not at all

questions.text: Upset

options.label: Very slightly or not at all

questions.text: Strong

options.label: Very slightly or not at all

questions.text: Guilty

options.label: Very slightly or not at all

questions.text: Scared

options.label: Very slightly or not at all

questions.text: Hostile

options.label: Very slightly or not at all

questions.text: Enthusiastic

options.label: Very slightly or not at all

questions.text: Proud

options.label: Very slightly or not at all

questions.text: Irritable

options.label: Very slightly or not at all

questions.text: Alert

options.label: Very slightly or not at all

questions.text: Ashamed

options.label: Very slightly or not at all

questions.text: Inspired

options.label: Very slightly or not at all

questions.text: Nervous

options.label: Very slightly or not at all

questions.text: Determined

options.label: Very slightly or not at all

questions.text: Attentive

options.label: Very slightly or not at all

questions.text: Jittery

options.label: Very slightly or not at all

questions.text: Active

options.label: Very slightly or not at all

questions.text: Afraid

options.label: Very slightly or not at all

psychometric_properties.validity: Strong factorial validity, low correlation between PA and NA subscales

instruments.title: Multidimensional Scale of Perceived Social Support (MSPSS)
instruments.description: A 12-item scale measuring perceived social support from three sources: family, friends, and significant others. Widely used in health and social psychology research.
instruments.source: Zimet, G. D., Dahlem, N. W., Zimet, S. G., & Farley, G. K. (1988). The Multidimensional Scale of Perceived Social Support. Journal of Personality Assessment, 52, 30-41. Free for research use.

questions.text: There is a special person who is around when I am in need
There is a special person with whom I can share my joys and sorrows
My family really tries to help me
I get the emotional help and support I need from my family
My friends really try to help me
I can count on my friends when things go wrong

psychometric_properties.validity: Strong construct validity and cross-cultural validation

instruments.title: Generalized Anxiety Disorder Scale (GAD-7)
instruments.description: A 7-item screening tool and severity measure for generalized anxiety disorder. Widely used in clinical practice and research for anxiety assessment.
instruments.source: Spitzer, R. L., Kroenke, K., Williams, J. B., & Löwe, B. (2006). A brief measure for assessing generalized anxiety disorder. Archives of Internal Medicine, 166, 1092-1097. Public domain.

questions.text: Feeling nervous, anxious or on edge
questions.timeframe: Over the last 2 weeks, how often have you been bothered by:

questions.text: Not being able to stop or control worrying
Worrying too much about different things
Trouble relaxing
Being so restless that it is hard to sit still
Becoming easily annoyed or irritable
Feeling afraid as if something awful might happen

clinical_cutoff.message: Score indicates possible generalized anxiety disorder - clinical evaluation recommended

psychometric_properties.validity: Excellent criterion validity for GAD diagnosis (sensitivity 89%, specificity 82%)

instruments.title: Patient Health Questionnaire-9 (PHQ-9)
instruments.description: A 9-item depression screening and severity measure based on DSM-IV criteria. The most widely used depression screening tool in primary care and research.
instruments.source: Kroenke, K., Spitzer, R. L., & Williams, J. B. (2001). The PHQ-9: validity of a brief depression severity measure. Journal of General Internal Medicine, 16, 606-613. Public domain.

questions.text: Little interest or pleasure in doing things
questions.timeframe: Over the last 2 weeks, how often have you been bothered by:

questions.text: Feeling down, depressed, or hopeless
Trouble falling or staying asleep, or sleeping too much
Feeling tired or having little energy
Poor appetite or overeating
Feeling bad about yourself - or that you are a failure or have let yourself or your family down
Trouble concentrating on things, such as reading the newspaper or watching television
Moving or speaking so slowly that other people could have noticed. Or the opposite - being so fidgety or restless that you have been moving around a lot more than usual
Thoughts that you would be better off dead, or of hurting yourself in some way

clinical_cutoff.message: Score indicates possible major depression - clinical evaluation recommended

suicide_risk.message: URGENT: Suicidal ideation reported - immediate clinical assessment required

psychometric_properties.validity: Excellent criterion validity for major depression (sensitivity 88%, specificity 88%)

instruments.title: Autism Spectrum Quotient-10 (AQ-10)
instruments.description: A brief 10-item screening questionnaire for autism spectrum conditions in adults. Derived from the original 50-item AQ scale.
instruments.source: Allison, C., Auyeung, B., & Baron-Cohen, S. (2012). Toward brief 'red flags' for autism screening: the short autism spectrum quotient and the short quantitative checklist in 1,000 cases and 3,000 controls. Journal of the American Academy of Child & Adolescent Psychiatry, 51, 202-212. Free for research use.

questions.text: I often notice small sounds when others do not
I usually concentrate more on the whole picture, rather than the small details
I find it easy to do more than one thing at once
If there is an interruption, I can switch back to what I was doing very quickly
I find it easy to 'read between the lines' when someone is talking to me
I know how to tell if someone listening to me is getting bored
When I'm reading a story I find it difficult to work out the characters' intentions
I like to collect information about categories of things
I find it easy to work out what someone is thinking or feeling just by looking at their face
I find it difficult to work out people's intentions

autism_screening.message: Score suggests possible autism spectrum condition - clinical assessment recommended

psychometric_properties.validity: Good sensitivity (88%) and specificity (91%) for autism spectrum conditions

instruments.title: Gratitude Questionnaire-6 (GQ-6)
instruments.description: A 6-item scale that assesses individual differences in the tendency to experience gratitude in daily life. Measures grateful dispositions and appreciation.
instruments.source: McCullough, M. E., Emmons, R. A., & Tsang, J. A. (2002). The grateful disposition: a conceptual and empirical topography. Journal of Personality and Social Psychology, 82, 112-127. Free for research use.

questions.text: I have so much in life to be thankful for
If I had to list everything that I felt grateful for, it would be a very long list
When I look at the world, I don't see much to be grateful for
I am grateful to a wide variety of people
As I get older I find myself more able to appreciate the people, events, and situations that have been part of my life history
Long amounts of time can go by before I feel grateful to something or someone

psychometric_properties.validity: Good convergent validity with other positive psychology measures

instruments.title: Empathy Quotient (EQ)
instruments.description: A 60-item questionnaire designed to measure empathy in adults. Assesses both cognitive and affective components of empathy.
instruments.source: Baron-Cohen, S., & Wheelwright, S. (2004). The empathy quotient: An investigation of adults with Asperger syndrome or high functioning autism, and normal sex differences. Journal of Autism and Developmental Disorders, 34, 163-175. Free for research use.

questions.text: I can easily tell if someone else wants to enter a conversation
I prefer animals to humans
I try to solve my own problems rather than discussing them with others
I find it difficult to explain to others things that I understand easily, when they don't understand it first time
I dream most nights

empathy_score.description: Empathy quotient score (partial scale - full scale has 60 items)

psychometric_properties.validity: Good construct validity and ability to discriminate between groups

instruments.title: Cognitive Failures Questionnaire (CFQ)
instruments.description: A 25-item questionnaire measuring the frequency of everyday cognitive lapses in memory, attention, and motor function. Widely used in cognitive psychology research.
instruments.source: Broadbent, D. E., Cooper, P. F., FitzGerald, P., & Parkes, K. R. (1982). The Cognitive Failures Questionnaire (CFQ) and its correlates. British Journal of Clinical Psychology, 21, 1-16. Free for research use.

questions.text: Do you read something and find you haven't been thinking about it and must read it again?
Do you forget appointments?
Do you fail to notice signposts on the road?
Do you forget where you put something like a newspaper or a book?
Do you fail to hear people speaking to you when you are doing something else?
Do you drop something?
Do you find you forget why you went from one part of the house to the other?
Do you fail to pick up items you meant to take with you before leaving a room or going out?
Do you bump into people?
Do you find you accidentally throw away the thing you want and keep what you meant to throw away?
Do you daydream when you ought to be listening to something?
Do you find you forget people's names?
Do you start doing one thing at home and get distracted into doing something else (unintentionally)?
Do you fail to listen to people's names when you are meeting them?
Do you say something and realize afterwards that it might be taken as insulting?
Do you fail to take in what someone is telling you?
Do you lose your temper and regret it?
Do you leave important letters unanswered for days?
Do you find you forget which way to turn on a road you know well but rarely use?
Do you fail to see what you want in a supermarket (although it's there)?
Do you find yourself suddenly wondering whether you've used a word correctly?
Do you have trouble making up your mind?
Do you find you forget what you came to the shops to buy?
Do you drop something because your attention is elsewhere?
Do you find you can't quite remember something although it's 'on the tip of your tongue'?

psychometric_properties.validity: Good construct validity; correlates with attention and memory measures

instruments.title: Barratt Impulsiveness Scale-11 (BIS-11)
instruments.description: A 30-item questionnaire measuring impulsiveness across three dimensions: attentional, motor, and non-planning impulsiveness. The most widely used self-report measure of impulsivity.
instruments.source: Patton, J. H., Stanford, M. S., & Barratt, E. S. (1995). Factor structure of the Barratt impulsiveness scale. Journal of Clinical Psychology, 51, 768-774. Free for research use.

questions.text: I plan tasks carefully
I do things without thinking
I make-up my mind quickly
I am happy-go-lucky
I don't pay attention
I have racing thoughts
I plan trips well ahead of time
I am self controlled
I concentrate easily
I save regularly
I squirm at plays or lectures
I am a careful thinker
I plan for job security
I say things without thinking
I like to think about complex problems
I change jobs
I act on the spur of the moment
I am a steady thinker
I change residences
I buy things on impulse
I can only think about one thing at a time
I change hobbies
I spend or charge more than I earn
I often have extraneous thoughts when thinking
I am more interested in the present than the future
I am restless at the theater or lectures
I like puzzles
I am future oriented
I am easily bored
I act on impulse

psychometric_properties.validity: Strong factorial validity and convergent validity with behavioral measures of impulsivity

instruments.title: General Self-Efficacy Scale (GSE)
instruments.description: A 10-item scale designed to assess a general sense of perceived self-efficacy with the aim to predict coping with daily hassles as well as adaptation after experiencing all kinds of stressful life events.
instruments.source: Schwarzer, R., & Jerusalem, M. (1995). Generalized Self-Efficacy scale. In J. Weinman, S. Wright, & M. Johnston (Eds.), Measures in health psychology (pp. 35-37). NFER-NELSON. Free for research use.

questions.text: I can always manage to solve difficult problems if I try hard enough
If someone opposes me, I can find the means and ways to get what I want
It is easy for me to stick to my aims and accomplish my goals
I am confident that I could deal efficiently with unexpected events
Thanks to my resourcefulness, I know how to handle unforeseen situations
I can solve most problems if I invest the necessary effort
I can remain calm when facing difficulties because I can rely on my coping abilities
When I am confronted with a problem, I can usually find several solutions
If I am in trouble, I can usually think of a solution
I can usually handle whatever comes my way

psychometric_properties.validity: Good construct validity and cross-cultural validity across 25 countries

instruments.title: Life Orientation Test-Revised (LOT-R)
instruments.description: A 10-item scale measuring dispositional optimism, the tendency to believe that one will generally experience good versus bad outcomes in life. Includes 4 filler items.
instruments.source: Scheier, M. F., Carver, C. S., & Bridges, M. W. (1994). Distinguishing optimism from neuroticism (and trait anxiety, self-mastery, and self-esteem): A reevaluation of the Life Orientation Test. Journal of Personality and Social Psychology, 67, 1063-1078. Free for research use.

questions.text: In uncertain times, I usually expect the best
It's easy for me to relax
If something can go wrong for me, it will
I'm always optimistic about my future
I enjoy my friends a lot
I rarely count on good things happening to me

optimism_score.description: Dispositional optimism score (0-24 for full 6-item scale)

psychometric_properties.validity: Good construct validity and predictive validity for health outcomes

instruments.title: Spheres of Control Scale (SOC-3)
instruments.description: A 30-item instrument measuring three domains of perceived control: Personal Control, Interpersonal Control, and Socio-Political Control. Provides a multidimensional view of locus of control.
instruments.source: Paulhus, D. L., & Van Selst, M. (1990). The Spheres of Control Scale: 10 years of research. Personality and Individual Differences, 11, 1029-1036. Available in public domain via Paulhus collection.

questions.text: When I get what I want, it's usually because I worked hard for it
When I make plans, I am almost certain to make them work
I prefer games involving some luck over games requiring pure skill
I can learn almost anything if I set my mind to it
My major accomplishments are entirely due to my hard work and ability
I usually don't set goals because I have a hard time following through on them
Bad luck has sometimes prevented me from achieving things
Almost anything is possible for me if I really want it
Most of what happens in my career will depend on my ability
Whether or not I get into a car accident depends mostly on how good a driver I am
I have no trouble making and keeping friends
I'm not good at guiding the course of a conversation with several others
I can usually develop a close personal relationship with someone I find appealing
I can usually steer a conversation toward the topics I want to talk about
If there's someone I want to meet I can usually arrange it
I often find it hard to get my point of view across to others
In attempting to smooth over a disagreement I usually make it worse
I find it easy to play an important part in most group situations
I have trouble figuring out how to please my friends
It's not always wise for me to plan too far ahead because many things turn out to be a matter of good or bad fortune
By taking an active part in political and social affairs, people can control world events
The average citizen can have an influence on government decisions
It is difficult for people to have much control over the things politicians do in office
Bad economic conditions are caused by world events that are beyond our control
Most people don't realize the extent to which their lives are controlled by accidental happenings
There is really no way ordinary people can influence what happens in world affairs
It is impossible to have any real influence within a large organization
In the long run people get the respect they deserve in this world
Becoming a success is a matter of hard work; luck has little or nothing to do with it
Getting people to do the right thing depends upon ability; luck has little or nothing to do with it

personal_control.description: Personal control subscale (1-6, higher = greater sense of personal control)

interpersonal_control.description: Interpersonal control subscale (1-6, higher = greater sense of interpersonal control)

sociopolitical_control.description: Socio-political control subscale (1-6, higher = greater sense of sociopolitical control)

total_control.description: Overall control beliefs across all three domains (1-6)

psychometric_properties.validity: Good discriminant validity between three control domains; factor analysis confirms three-factor structure

instruments.title: Trust Scale
instruments.description: An 18-item scale measuring trust in close relationships across three dimensions: predictability, dependability, and faith. Assesses relationship-specific trust.
instruments.source: Rempel, J. K., Holmes, J. G., & Zanna, M. P. (1985). Trust in close relationships. Journal of Personality and Social Psychology, 49, 95-112. Free for research use.

questions.text: My partner is primarily interested in his/her own welfare
There are times when my partner cannot be trusted
My partner is perfectly honest and truthful with me
I can predict how my partner will act tomorrow
My partner's behavior is very consistent
Even when I don't know how my partner will react, I feel comfortable telling him/her anything about myself, even those things of which I am ashamed

psychometric_properties.validity: Good construct validity and predictive validity for relationship outcomes

instruments.title: Brief COPE Inventory
instruments.description: A 28-item shortened version of the COPE inventory that measures different coping strategies people use to deal with stress. Assesses 14 different coping strategies.
instruments.source: Carver, C. S. (1997). You want to measure coping but your protocol's too long: Consider the brief COPE. International Journal of Behavioral Medicine, 4, 92-100. Free for research use.

questions.text: I've been turning to work or other activities to take my mind off things.

options.label: I haven't been doing this at all
I've been doing this a little bit
I've been doing this a medium amount
I've been doing this a lot

questions.text: I've been concentrating my efforts on doing something about the situation I'm in.

options.label: I haven't been doing this at all
I've been doing this a little bit
I've been doing this a medium amount
I've been doing this a lot

questions.text: I've been saying to myself "this isn't real".

options.label: I haven't been doing this at all
I've been doing this a little bit
I've been doing this a medium amount
I've been doing this a lot

options.label: I haven't been doing this at all
I've been doing this a little bit

I've been doing this a lot

options.label: I haven't been doing this at all

I've been doing this a lot

options.label: I haven't been doing this at all

I've been doing this a lot

options.label: I haven't been doing this at all

I've been doing this a lot

options.label: I haven't been doing this at all
I've been doing this a little bit
I've been doing this a medium amount
I've been doing this a lot

options.label: I haven't been doing this at all

options.label: I haven't been doing this at all

I've been doing this a medium amount
I've been doing this a lot

options.label: I haven't been doing this at all
I've been doing this a little bit
I've been doing this a medium amount

options.label: I haven't been doing this at all

options.label: I haven't been doing this at all

options.label: I haven't been doing this at all
I've been doing this a little bit
I've been doing this a medium amount
I've been doing this a lot

questions.text: I've been doing something to think about it less, such as movies, TV, reading, daydreaming, sleeping, or shopping.

options.label: I haven't been doing this at all
I've been doing this a little bit
I've been doing this a medium amount
I've been doing this a lot

options.label: I haven't been doing this at all
I've been doing this a little bit

options.label: I haven't been doing this at all

I've been doing this a lot

psychometric_properties.validity: Good construct validity; 14-factor structure confirmed in later studies

instruments.title: Connor-Davidson Resilience Scale-10 (CD-RISC-10)
instruments.description: A 10-item scale measuring psychological resilience - the ability to cope with adversity. This is a shortened version of the original 25-item CD-RISC.
instruments.source: Campbell‐Sills, L., & Stein, M. B. (2007). Psychometric analysis and refinement of the Connor–Davidson resilience scale (CD‐RISC): validation of a 10‐item measure of resilience. Journal of Traumatic Stress, 20, 1019-1028. Permission required for commercial use, free for research.

questions.text: I am able to adapt when changes occur
questions.instruction: Please indicate how much you agree with the following statements as they apply to you over the last month.

questions.text: I can deal with whatever comes my way
I try to see the humorous side of things when I am faced with problems
Having to cope with stress can make me stronger
I tend to bounce back after illness, injury, or other hardships

total_resilience.description: Total resilience score (partial scale - full CD-RISC-10 has 10 items)

psychometric_properties.validity: Good construct validity and convergent validity with other resilience measures

instruments.title: Mindful Attention Awareness Scale (MAAS)
instruments.description: A 15-item scale designed to assess a core characteristic of dispositional mindfulness - open or receptive awareness of and attention to what is taking place in the present.
instruments.source: Brown, K. W., & Ryan, R. M. (2003). The benefits of being present: mindfulness and its role in psychological well-being. Journal of Personality and Social Psychology, 84, 822-848. Free for research use.

questions.text: I could be experiencing some emotion and not be conscious of it until some time later
questions.instruction: Below is a collection of statements about your everyday experience. Please indicate how frequently or infrequently you currently have each experience.

questions.text: I break or spill things because of carelessness, not paying attention, or thinking of something else
I find it difficult to stay focused on what's happening in the present
I tend to walk quickly to get where I'm going without paying attention to what I experience along the way
I tend not to notice feelings of physical tension or discomfort until they really grab my attention
I forget a person's name almost as soon as I've been told it for the first time
It seems I am 'running on automatic' without much awareness of what I'm doing
I rush through activities without being really attentive to them
I get so focused on the goal I want to achieve that I lose touch with what I am doing right now to get there
I do jobs or tasks automatically, without being aware of what I'm doing
I find myself listening to someone with one ear, doing something else at the same time
I drive places on 'automatic pilot' and then wonder why I went there
I find myself preoccupied with the future or the past
I find myself doing things without paying attention
I snack without being aware that I'm eating

mindfulness_score.description: Mindful attention awareness score - mean of all 15 items (1-6 scale)

mindfulness_level.description: Level of mindful awareness based on total score

psychometric_properties.validity: Strong construct validity and predictive validity for psychological well-being

instruments.title: Functional Assessment of Chronic Illness Therapy-Spiritual Well-Being (FACIT-Sp)
instruments.description: A 12-item scale measuring spiritual well-being in individuals with chronic illness. Assesses meaning, peace, and faith dimensions of spirituality.
instruments.source: Peterman, A. H., Fitchett, G., Brady, M. J., Hernandez, L., & Cella, D. (2002). Measuring spiritual well-being in people with cancer: the functional assessment of chronic illness therapy—Spiritual Well-being Scale (FACIT-Sp). Annals of Behavioral Medicine, 24, 49-58. Free for research use.

questions.text: I feel peaceful
questions.instruction: Below is a list of statements that other people with your illness have said are important. Please circle or mark one number per line to indicate your response as it applies to the past 7 days.

questions.text: I have a reason for living
My life has been productive
I have trouble feeling peace of mind
I feel a sense of purpose in my life
I find comfort in my faith or spiritual beliefs

psychometric_properties.validity: Good construct validity and convergent validity with other spirituality measures

instruments.title: Strengths and Difficulties Questionnaire (SDQ)
instruments.description: A 25-item behavioral screening questionnaire for children and adolescents ages 3-16. Measures emotional symptoms, conduct problems, hyperactivity, peer problems, and prosocial behavior.
instruments.source: Goodman, R. (1997). The Strengths and Difficulties Questionnaire: a research note. Journal of Child Psychology and Psychiatry, 38, 581-586. Free for clinical and research use.
instruments.license: Free for clinical and research use

questions.text: Considerate of other people's feelings
questions.instruction: For each item, please mark the box for Not True, Somewhat True or Certainly True. It would help us if you answered all items as best you can even if you are not absolutely certain.

questions.text: Restless, overactive, cannot stay still for long
Often complains of headaches, stomach-aches or sickness
Shares readily with other children, for example toys, treats, pencils
Often loses temper
Rather solitary, prefers to play alone
Generally well behaved, usually does what adults request
Many worries or often seems worried
Helpful if someone is hurt, upset or feeling ill
Constantly fidgeting or squirming
Has at least one good friend
Often fights with other children or bullies them
Often unhappy, depressed or tearful
Generally liked by other children
Easily distracted, concentration wanders
Nervous in new situations, easily loses confidence
Kind to younger children
Often lies or cheats
Picked on or bullied by other children
Often offers to help others (parents, teachers, other children)
Thinks things out before acting
Steals from home, school or elsewhere
Gets along better with adults than with other children
Many fears, easily scared
Good attention span, sees chores or homework through to the end

psychometric_properties.validity: Good criterion validity; widely used in population screening

instruments.title: Oxford Happiness Questionnaire
instruments.description: A 29-item scale measuring personal happiness and life satisfaction. Designed to measure subjective well-being from a positive psychology perspective.
instruments.source: Hills, P., & Argyle, M. (2002). The Oxford Happiness Questionnaire: a compact scale for the measurement of psychological well-being. Personality and Individual Differences, 33, 1073-1082. Free for research use.

questions.text: I don’t feel particularly pleased with the way I am.
I am intensely interested in other people.
I feel that life is very rewarding.
I have very warm feelings towards almost everyone.
I rarely wake up feeling rested.
I am not particularly optimistic about the future.
I find most things amusing.
I am always committed and involved.
Life is good.
I do not think that the world is a good place.
I laugh a lot.
I am well satisfied about everything in my life.
I don’t think I look attractive.
There is a gap between what I would like to do and what I have done.
I am very happy.
I find beauty in some things.
I always have a cheerful effect on others.
I can fit in (find time for) everything I want.
I feel that I am not especially in control of my life.
I feel able to take anything on.
I feel fully mentally alert.
I often experience joy and elation.
I don’t find it easy to make decisions.
I don’t have a particular sense of meaning and purpose in my life.
I feel I have a great deal of energy.
I usually have a good influence on events.
I don’t have fun with other people.
I don’t feel particularly healthy.
I don’t have particularly happy memories of the past.

happiness_score.description: Overall happiness score (mean of 29 items, reverse scoring applied where indicated)

psychometric_properties.validity: Good construct validity and convergent validity with other well-being measures
